Configuring Captive Portal

Use the Captive Portal feature to provide controlled, authenticated access to the Internet and your network resources, without compromising security. A captive portal displays a special web page to authenticate clients before they can use the Internet. You can configure Captive Portal verification to allow access for both guest and authenticated network users.

Configure Captive Portal instances for each virtual wireless network on your device by associating it with a portal profile.

Creating Captive Portal Profiles

To create a captive portal profile:

 1. Choose Wireless > Captive Portal > Portal Profile. In the Portal Profile Table section, click Add Row. To modify the portal profile provided on the device, check the Default_Portal_Profile box and click Edit.

 2. Enter a name for your Captive Portal profile.

 3. Choose if you want to use the profile to authenticate guest users or users on your network.

 4. To redirect users to a URL after authentication, enable Auto Redirect URL, and enter a fully qualified domain name or IP address in the Redirect URL field. For example, include http:// in the URL.

 5. In the Session Timeout field, specify the number of minutes that the device will keep an authentication session open with the associated wireless client. The default timeout is 60 minutes.

 6. Select a font color for the text that you want to display on the page.

 7. Specify the text that you want to display, such as the name of your organization, the label text for username and password fields, and the label on the Login button.

 8. Enter standard Copyright text associated with your company.

 9. In the Error 1 and Error 2 fields, enter the error messages that you want to display to clients when login fails and when the maximum number of connections is exceeded.

 10. To use a check box to allow users to accept terms of use before they continue, enable Agreement. The text in the Agreement Text field will be displayed as the label for the checkbox.

 11. Enter the acceptance terms that you want to display to users in the Acceptance Use Policy field.

 12. In the Upload Files section, choose files to upload your company logo and background files in keeping with your company’s branding guidelines. Save your profile.

To preview this profile, choose Captive Portal > Portal Page Preview, and select the profile from the Portal Profile drop-down list.

 

Configuring Captive Portal Instances

To configure a captive portal instance for your device:

 1. Choose Wireless > Basic Settings.

 2. In the Wireless Table section, check the Enable box for the SSID for which you want to configure a captive portal. Click Edit.

 3. Select a portal profile for the SSID.

You can create up to four captive portals using the SSIDs for your device. To create a new portal profile, select Create a new Portal Profile from the drop-down list. Choose Default_Portal_Profile to use the portal profile provided on your device.

 4. Check the Enable box to enable the captive portal for the SSID.

 5. Save your captive portal instances.

 

Creating Captive Portal User Accounts

To create a captive portal user account:

 1. Choose Wireless > Captive Portal > User Accounts.

 2. Click Add Row.

 3. Enter a username and password. Reenter the password to verify it.

We recommended that the password contains no dictionary words from any language, and is a mix of letters (both uppercase and lowercase), numbers, and symbols. The password can be up to 64 characters long.

 4. In the Access Time (Minutes) field, specify the duration after which the authentication session will timeout.

 5. To import usernames and passwords from a CSV file, click Import. The Administration > Users page is displayed. In the Import Username and Password section, click Browse to locate the file, and click Import. See Importing User Accounts for more information.

 6. Save your user accounts.
